prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Flux estimate: To get our line flux estimate for [CI] 1-0, we scale from the estimate for [CI] 2-1 (given in the appropriate science goal). The characteristic line flux ratio of [CI] 2-1 / [CI] 1-0 is about 2 to 3 (with the precise value depending on pressure and radiation field). Accounting for the difference in frequency, and assuming the two lines have idnetical velocity widths, we find 2.4 mJy for the total flux. If we divide this among the solid angle of the lensed arc (corresponding to 5 synthesized beams), we find 0.48 mJy/beam. By setting the sensitivity goal to 150 microJansky per beam, we expect a 3 sigma detection per beam, and will achive s/n > 5 upon coaddition of the entire lensed image.
Here we have one basebands on a lines (CI 1-0), using FDM mode, and three basebands on the continuum, using TDM mode.
Spatial structure: This arc has a longest dimension of 8 arcseconds, and a width of about 1 arcsecond.
Continuum: We use the continuum level that was measured at 370 micron rest wavelength during our earlier observations.

Our correlator setup is chosen to maximize frequency coverage (1875 MHz/baseband), avoid the highest data rates through spectral averaging (8) or the use fo TD mode, and still keep many spectral resolution elements across the typical width of a galaxy's emission line.
This arc has a longest dimension of 8 arcseconds, and a width of 1 arcsecond.

Flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 2e-18 W/m2 for this source. Scaling from that, the [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 2e-20 W/m2 or 2e-17 erg/cm2/s. If we instead scale from the FIR continuum, using the smallest ratio of [CI]/FIR yet observed (6e-6), we obtain a line flux estimate of 2.5e-18 erg/cm2/s. Spreading that over 500 km/s of line width (based on the broad observed [CII] line from our Herschel program) leads to 0.66 mJy. If we take this to be spread over the size of the source (about 4 arcsec, or 2.5 synthesized beams), and ask for a 4 sigma detection after coaddding both spectrally and spatially, we obtain a final time requirement of 1.02 hours.
If our cycle 2 observations of this target are taken and show high signal-to-noise, this observation would not need to happen. However, this science goal is not a simple repeat of the cycle 2 goal for this object and line. It has an increased integration time that will yield a more powerful measurement, which will be valuable either if our cycle 2 program is not completed, or if the signal-to-noise in our ten minute cycle 2 observation turns out to be low.

Our correlator setup is chosen to maximize frequency coverage (1875 MHz/ baseband), avoid the highest data rates through spectral averaging (8) or the use of TDM mode, and still keep many resolution elements across the width of the target galaxy's emission lines.

The target is about 1 by 4 arcseconds in size. We do not want to resolve out too much flux, so we set our requested resolution to just 1.0". WE also want the largest angular scale for the observing to equal or exceed the size of the lensed object. It does.

Flux estimate: Our prior program obtained between 500 and 600 seconds of band 6 observations for the [CI] 2-1 transition. We have a marginal 2 sigma detection in this observation. We want to get a solid detection. To go from 2 sigma to 5 sigma, we need to integrate for roughly (2.5**2)=6 times longer, which comes to one hour.
We verified that this will correspond to a good measurement (or very stringent limit) on the [CI]/FIR ratio. Accounting for a 200 km/s line width (based on the [CII] measurement from Herschel HIFI), the smallest [CI]/FIR ratio yet reported in the literature (6e-6) would correspond to a flux density of 1.2 mJy. Assuming this flux is spread over about 5x more solid angle than the synthesized beam, and asking for a signal-to-noise of four overall (hence 4/sqrt(5) = 1.8 in each beam), we obtain a sensitivity goal of 134 microJansky per beam RMS. Note, because we divided our signal into parts to account for the spatial extent of this lensed source, the s/n looks low-- but we will combine multiple images of the gravitationally lensed target and our final s/n will be at least 4, even for an extremely low line-to-continuum ratio.
The corresponding uncertainty on the L(CI) / L(FIR) ratio comes to about +- 1.5e-6, and the required time is 44 minutes on source and 1.2 hours in total. The CO 7-6 line is typically comparable in strength to the [CI] 2-1 line, and should have roughly similar signal-to-noise ratio.
Here we have two basebands on lines (CI and CO 7-6), using FDM mode, and two basebands on the continuum, using TDM mode.
Continuum: We use the continuum flux density measured under our previous program.

Our correlator setup is chosen to maximize frequency coverage (1875 MHz/baseband), avoid the highest data rates through spectral averaging (8) or the use of TDM mode, and still keep many resolution elements across the typical width of a galaxy's emission line.
This arc has a longest dimension of 8 arcseconds, and a width of about 1 arcsecond.

Flux estimate: The [CII] 158 micron line has a flux of about 2e-18 W/m2 for this source. Scaling from that, the [CI] 370 micron line should be about 1% of [CII] 158 micron line. So the expected flux is 2e-20 W/m2 or 2e-17 erg/cm2/s. We obtain a somewht more conservative [i.e. smaller] answer if we instead scale from the FIR continuum, using the smallest ratio of [CI]370/FIR yet observed (6e-6), and combining it with the typical ratio of f([CI]1-0) / f([CI]2-1) = 2 to 3. Here we obtain a line flux estimate near 1e-18 erg/cm2/s. Spreading that over 500 km/s of line width (based on the broad observed [CII] line from our Herschel program) leads to 0.40 mJy. If we take this to be spread over the size of the source (about 4x1 arcsec, or 2.5 synthesized beams), and ask for a 4 sigma detection after coaddding both spectrally and spatially, we obtain a final time requirement of 0.9 hours.
We note that because our entries in parts of the AOT file are for a single primary beam, while we will coadd the extended lensed images of our target to achieve a final s/n that is greater than 3 in 1/3 of the line width and greater than 5 overall.

Our correlator setup is chosen to maximize frequency coverage (1875 MHz/ baseband), avoid the highest data rates through spectral averaging (8) or the use of TDM mode, and still keep many resolution elements across the width of the target galaxy's emission lines.

The target is about 1 by 4 arcseconds in size. We do not want to resolve out too much flux, so we set our requested resolution to just 1.0". We also want the largest angular scale for the observing to equal or exceed the size of the lensed object. It does.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We request 4.4 hours of ALMA time to observe [CI] (2-1), [CI](1-0) and CO (7-6) lines in 2 extremely lensed, but otherwise typical star-forming galaxies at redshifts z=2-3. These galaxies are part of our survey of [CII](158 micron) and [OI] (63 micron) lines with Herschel (the Herschel Extreme Lensing Line Observations 'HELLO'). The HELLO sample of normal galaxies forms an ideal complement to studies of dusty starbursts at z=2.
By themselves, the two [CI] lines will enable determination of excitation temperatures, neutral C column density and mass independent of any other measurements.
Combined with the Herschel [CII] line measurements, the [CI] and CO lines will give a complete picture of the physical conditions, including density, far-ultraviolet flux, temperature, and pressures in atomic and molecular gas. With the [CII], [OI], [CI], and multiple CO lines we will have the total cooling budget and we can determine whether their ISM at z=2 is fundamentally different from the local universe. ALMA's spatial resolution will also allow a study of spatially resolved kinematics of these galaxies, among which some show outflows and some show cold rotation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Earth and Space Exploration, Arizona State University
